summary: The appellant, Ajayi Omokaro, was convicted of murder based entirely on his confessions, one of which was made before a European Assistant Commissioner of Police. On appeal, the sole issue was whether a conviction could stand on such a basis. The West Africa Court of Appeal upheld the conviction, citing R. v. Sykes as authority that a conviction solely on confessional evidence is valid if the confessions are proven genuine. The trial judge had carefully examined the circumstances and found the confessions authentic. The appeal was dismissed.
rationaleHighlights: Conviction based solely on confessions is legally permissible if proven genuine.
Trial judge conducted thorough inquiry into circumstances of confessions.
Precedent (R. v. Sykes) supports admissibility and sufficiency of confession evidence.
Confession made before European Assistant Commissioner of Police adds credibility.
confidenceNotes: The case relies heavily on precedent (R. v. Sykes) and judicial assessment of confession authenticity. Confidence is high due to clear judicial reasoning and citation of binding authority.
